Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:: Investigation of Distance and Orientation Dependence for Electron Transfer Between Organic Molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
The organic molecule, pyrene, is used in a multitude of applications, including molecular recognition and sensing, molecular electronics, light emitting diodes, determination of micro-environments of polymers and liquids, etc. Fluorescence quenching of pyrene with amines proceeds by an electron-transfer mechanism where an amine may donate an electron to the pyrene molecule. The process of electron-transfer must meet specific criteria for the orientation of and distance between the lone pair of electrons of an amine quencher and pyrene. In general, the approach and distance of quenchers to aromatic molecules are inferred from less than definitive data in which the existence of a favorable mutual orientation and distance is assumed. This award supports research (1) to examine in greater detail the distance and orientation dependence of this type of electron/charge transfer; and (2) to analyze this process by equipment not accessible to Georgetown University. Particularly, laser flash spectrophotometry under the expertise of Prof. Xian-Fu Zhang at Hebei Normal University of Science and Technology in Heibei, China. The LFS will be used to examine directly the degree of and separation distance between radical ions immediately after electron-transfer.

Our studies examine the approach of a variety of amines and the distance needed for them to undergo electron/charge transfer to tetrakisarylpyrene (TKPy) molecules in which access to the รฐ-system is restricted. The presence of a charge-transfer, excited-state complex (exciplex) is observable in emission from the interaction between the TkPys and aromatic amines. The degree of charge- or electron-transfer is dependent on the distance between quencher and TkPys at the moment of complex formation, and it varies with the type and shape of the amine. The conclusions obtained from these studies are clearly applicable to a wide variety of other systems in which fluorescence from an aromatic moiety is being quenched.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Ministry of Science and Technology of China.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our studies examine of the approach of the quencher and the distance of electron and charge transfer by measuring the dynamics of the excited singlet state interactions between sterically encumbered tetrakisarylpyrene (TkPy) molecules, which restrict access to the π-system, and amines of different size, shape, and half-wave oxidation potentials.  Systems involving both aliphatic and aromatic amine quenchers have been studied and each type interacts differently with the TkPys; the most prominent difference is the presence of an emissive charge-transfer complex (exciplex), observable from the interaction of PyOMe with aromatic amines, but not with aliphatic ones that also are excellent quenchers of the TkPy fluorescence.  The degree to which charge- or electron-transfer occurs is dependent on the distance between quencher and a TkPy at the moment of complex formation.  This distance varies with the size, shape, and halfwave oxidation potential of the amine. The conclusions obtained from these studies are clearly applicable to a wide variety of other systems in which fluorescence from an aromatic moiety is being quenched.

Although we have been able to make several interesting observations for the TkPy aromatic amine systems, such as the formation of emissive exciplexes, we are unable to assign definitively mechanism(s) for some of the observed phenomena. Clearly, transient absorption instrumentation, which has not been accessible to the PI, would aid in the interpretation of the data in hand and a much more comprehensive picture of the processes involved.

The U.S. NSF Grant allowed for collaboration in China in a lab knowledgeable and skilled in transient absorption spectroscopy. The PI was trained on the instrument (transient absorption spectroscopy) and used it to characterize electron- and charge-transfer interactions in solution. The primary results indicate that electron-transfer is slow in the presence of steric congestion and de-stabilizes charge-transfer complexes. The complete results have been submitted for publication and are in review. The PI took full advantage of their time in China and in addition to research, increased contact with old collaborators while attending China’s national chemistry meeting hosted by the Chinese Chemical Society.
